item.title: Oil Pauses as Demand Outlook Appears Uncertain
item.description: Oil prices were steady with investors waiting to see if anything comes from speculation the U.S. is considering easing sanctions against Venezuela and Iran, which could open the door to more crude exports.

item.title: Metals Rise as China Looks to Boost Economic Support
item.description: Base metals and gold rose, with ING highlighting that China introduced support measures on Monday for transport, property and other infrastructure projects. “These measures have helped broader sentiment in financial markets.”

item.title: New Zealand Plans Digital-Services Tax for Multinationals
item.description: New Zealand said it will prepare to impose a digital-services tax on large multinational companies from 2025 following delays to a planned overhaul of international tax rules.

item.title: Dollar Trade Steadies After Jackson Hole Meeting
item.description: Dollar trading steadied following the Jackson Hole meeting, including the Powell speech, as it contained no major surprises and calm returned to the market, Natixis Research said.

item.title: German Consumer Mood To Weaken
item.description: German consumer sentiment is forecast to deteriorate in September, with the GfK forward-looking index at a slightly-below consensus minus 25.5, reflecting gloomier income expectations and prospects for the country’s economy.

item.title: Standard Chartered Exits Aviation Leasing
item.description: Standard Chartered has sold its global aviation finance leasing business for an initial $700 million to a Saudi wealth fund unit.

item.title: Germany to Conduct Bond Auction and Syndicated Tap on Tuesday
item.description: Primary market activity in eurozone government bonds is set to pick up on Tuesday, with Germany conducting a bond auction and a syndicated tap.

item.title: Nikkei Rises 0.2%, Led by Retail, Real-Estate Stocks
item.description: Japanese stocks ended slightly higher, led by gains in retail and real-estate stocks, as concerns about borrowing costs continue to abate.

item.title: Toyota Suspends Operations at Factories in Japan Due to Malfunction
item.description: Toyota Motor temporarily halted operations at 12 of its 14 factories in Japan on Tuesday due to a malfunction with its systems that left it unable to procure parts as needed.

item.title: Q&A With Volvo Group's Karin Svensson
item.description: The sustainability chief of the Swedish truck and bus maker discusses the trek to net zero by 2040, the electrification of transport and the multiple parties needed to get incentives and charging stations in place.

item.title: Why Banned Cotton From China Is So Hard to Keep Out of the U.S.
item.description: The U.S. has banned many cotton imports from China over concerns it is harvested by forced labor in Xinjiang. We unpack the complexity of the supply chain to explain why experts believe much of the cotton is still making its way to the U.S.

item.title: The U.S. and China agreed to set up new communication channels for economic and commercial issues, Commerce Secretary Raimondo said, including a bilateral forum to discuss export-control measures to reduce misunderstanding of national-security policies.
item.description: The U.S. and China agreed to set up new communication channels for economic and commercial issues, Commerce Secretary Raimondo said, including a bilateral forum to discuss export-control measures to reduce misunderstanding of national-security policies.

item.title: The EU should be ready to take in Ukraine, Balkan nations and other candidate countries from 2030, an official said, the first time the bloc has set a target date for its potential expansion.
item.description: The EU should be ready to take in Ukraine, Balkan nations and other candidate countries from 2030, an official said, the first time the bloc has set a target date for its potential expansion.

item.title: Hawaiian Electric said its power lines weren't responsible for the wildfire that destroyed the town of Lahaina, and blamed Maui County firefighters for an inadequate response.
item.description: Hawaiian Electric said its power lines weren’t responsible for the wildfire that destroyed the town of Lahaina, and blamed Maui County firefighters for an inadequate response.

item.title: Foxconn founder Terry Gou said he plans to run for Taiwan's presidency, complicating a contest that could reshape the island's testy relations with Beijing and affect U.S. policy toward China.
item.description: Foxconn founder Terry Gou said he plans to run for Taiwan’s presidency, complicating a contest that could reshape the island’s testy relations with Beijing and affect U.S. policy toward China.

item.title: Student-loan borrowers at the end of pandemic relief will start owing interest as of Friday, and are learning of new payment schedules from servicers they might have never heard of.
item.description: Student-loan borrowers at the end of pandemic relief will start owing interest as of Friday, and are learning of new payment schedules from servicers they might have never heard of.

item.title: Meadows told a court he was acting in line with his duties as Trump's White House chief of staff when he set up meetings and called Georgia officials asking about alleged election fraud in the state after Trump's 2020 loss.
item.description: Meadows told a court he was acting in line with his duties as Trump’s White House chief of staff when he set up meetings and called Georgia officials asking about alleged election fraud in the state after Trump’s 2020 loss.

item.title: Trump's trial on charges that he conspired to overturn his 2020 election loss is set to start March 4, one day before Super Tuesday, when voters in 14 states will cast primary ballots for the next presidential election.
item.description: Trump’s trial on charges that he conspired to overturn his 2020 election loss is set to start March 4, one day before Super Tuesday, when voters in 14 states will cast primary ballots for the next presidential election.

item.title: American Airlines was fined $4.1 million for keeping passengers on dozens of flights stuck on the ground for more than three hours.
item.description: American Airlines was fined $4.1 million for keeping passengers on dozens of flights stuck on the ground for more than three hours.

item.title: Major U.S. stock indexes kicked off the week with gains as the S&P 500 and Dow both rose 0.6% and the Nasdaq advanced 0.8%.
item.description: Major U.S. stock indexes kicked off the week with gains as the S&P 500 and Dow both rose 0.6% and the Nasdaq advanced 0.8%.
